Claim: Feminism is a force for good in the world.
Feminist spaces are open and accepting places for political discussion.
Feminism creates a space for women's views, concerns, and issues to be heard in what has traditionally been - and continues to be - a political environment very much dominated by men.
Feminism helps breed recognition and support for under-represented female leaders and ideas.
The existence of powerful female leaders can change social perceptions of women's abilities and opportunities. This could make it possible for more women to advance in a range of roles.
Female leaders can provide inspiration for other women who aspire to positions of influence.
There is no reason to believe that women particularly benefit from other women holding leadership positions.
Margaret Thatcher, ex-British Prime Minister, notoriously decried feminism and stood against advancements justified on the basis of gender.

Female leaders understand the specific problems facing women, from a first person perspective, in a way that a male leader cannot. This different perspective makes change in a world that often overlooks women.
As women gain equal rights, societies become more peaceful, making it more likely that the voices of others are considered in politics.
Conflicts are 35% more likely to be resolved, and remain peaceful for another 15 years, when there are women involved in the formal peace process.
As TERFs take on powerful roles in society, perpetuating colonial and exploitative thinking, many women may be excluded, lose their rights, and feel like their voice is not being considered.
Feminism keeps women's rights in popular discourse and at the top of people's minds.
Banners for feminist marches are often eye-catching, drawing attention both at the time and at later art exhibitions. This keeps the campaign goal in people's memories.
The Guerrilla Girls, a feminist art collective, keep their critiques of museum cultures within the public consciousness with their bold and engaging activism.
Increased social media use makes it easier to highlight injustice; it may be that certain platforms help to keep women's rights relevant rather than the nature of the feminist movement itself.
It is unlikely that men in politics are wholly free from the influence of women; they probably advocate for the women in their lives whose interests they care about.

Frederick Pethick-Lawrence, husband of socialist activist Emmeline, avidly supported suffrage and later became an MP in the UK. He is likely to have ensured his wife's perspective was integrated in his politics.
Even if a man nominally advocates for women's views, through the process of horse-trading he may be inclined to trade them off for political gain given the issues do not affect him directly.
While the public face of politics may appear to be male-heavy, many platforms exist within the socio-political system that allow women's issues to be raised or tabled.
Women have the freedom of speech and many use it to make their voices heard through various forms of media, publishing, and social media platforms.
Academic journals, like the Feminist Review, promote feminist perspectives and ensure they are heard in academia.
Women often make ample use of social media platforms to share information relevant to them, including political campaigns.
Sexist harassment online may have a chilling effect on women's speech as it is both rampant, and a threat to their safety.
Women experience sexism through gendered censorship meaning that they struggle to defend their rights. Feminism is necessary to fight this and reduce the potential for further oppressive action.

Those who use social media for activism are already likely to be politically engaged, so the platform privileges men who are seen as traditionally political and appealed to. As such, this platform does not meaningfully expand speech for women.
There are many women's organizations that operate under the banner of feminism, and also independent of feminism.
Even without the platform of feminism, women in most countries may engage politically by voting, participating in ballot initiatives, lobbying, supporting campaigns, and running for office.
While legally women retain the right to vote in many places, due to inherent power imbalances, close male friends and relatives can heavily inform or dictate a woman's political choices.
In many places, women still face systemic and societal barriers to voting.
Mutilation of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 has disenfranchised minority women and kept millions from voting in the US.

Platforms for women's voices often privilege those with the time and money to be politically engaged; amongst poorer women, political engagement is low. This means fewer key issues may be heard in these spaces.
Feminism adds a new perspective to conventional views on social and political issues.
Feminism has helped women to express their sexuality more openly and deconstruct the taboos encompassing nudity, sensuality, romance, and connectedness.
The modern resurgence of burlesque uses feminism to empower women, encouraging them to reclaim objectification and take control of their bodies and their audience's attitudes towards it.
Some feminists have readily embraced the topic of sex, evaluating how it is discursively mediated. This opens space to discuss all forms of sex and create more just systems of desire.
Many anti-abortion feminists continue to construct and reinforce taboos regarding impurity and sexual promiscuity.
One of the most famous American feminists, Susan B. Anthony, likened the severity of abortion to the murder of wives and infant children.

Not all feminists have liberatory views of sex; historically, radical anti-sex work feminists have paired with conservative politicians to censor pornography and limit conversations on its role in society.
Many feminists treat female submissives (a.k.a. femsubs) as traitors to their cause.
Submissive behaviour can be incredibly empowering; practitioners of shibari often find it therapeutic. When feminists stigmatise sex on the grounds of politics, they often ignore considerable nuance.
Female submissiveness is often connected to troubling orientalising tropes that can have real world harms. It is useful for a political movement to push back against this.

Few feminists seek to directly target practitioners, instead they critique the increased normalisation of BDSM. This activism amplifies complaints from young people who often feel coerced into violent sex acts.
Attempts to limit sex-positive feminist movements have largely failed.
Feminists have consistently been involved with campaigns for healthier eating habits, and have worked to reduce the desire to eat meat with every meal.
A number of feminist icons began the fight for animal rights and veganism in the early 20th century.
By pushing back against the overconsumption of meat, feminists have helped save countless people from coronary artery disease and other diseases.

Campaigns for vegetarianism and veganism can often be colonial and ignore sustainable indigenous food production practices in favour of a monolithic perspective on food. Feminist involvement therefore may not be positive.
Feminists offer cultural critiques on art, movies, television, and other cultural phenomena, helping us better understand them (p. 180).
Cynthia Enloe added a feminist perspective to international relations theory when she focused on the role of military bases, diplomats' wives, and backlashes to nationalism.
The Venus of Willendorf was originally assumed to be a fertility figure, meant to inspire men, until a woman noted that it was more likely to be a self-portrait.
Most celebrated works of art or literature prior to feminist criticism normalised patriarchal and androcentric standards (p. 25). Feminist writings offered the other side of the story.
There are few feminist texts in school curricula, which denotes the lack of an ability to enact widespread understanding and change within society (p. 110).

Nearly one-quarter of adults in the US did not read a book in 2020 and nearly one-third of adults in the UK do not read in their free time; if a feminist text is not part of required reading in the classroom, it is unlikely that it would ever be read.
As reading is often segregated along gendered lines, male curriculum writers may be biased away from feminist texts. This does not mean that such perspectives are not valuable.
Given the unscientific nature of feminist thought, regardless of the critiques offered, people may be skeptical when engaging with them.
New perspectives are not necessarily good perspectives.
Traditions can be incredibly comforting, offering a refuge in troubled times. When these are disrupted by new ideologies, people may feel more vulnerable.
Innovation through new perspectives can be reckless and short-sighted, driving people towards negative long-term outcomes. As such, new views should be approached with skepticism.

Existing perspectives often exist due to path dependency and enshrine oppressive action by removing people's ability to pushback; when new movements disrupt this, whilst initially causing unrest, the world is better overall.
Certain traditions - maintained as part of the status quo - are jarring and can make people feel as uncomfortable as changes to society.
Liberalism predicates equality under the law, and has done so outside of direct feminist influence.
Unlike liberalism, feminism focuses on a specific group. This switches the terms of the argument from universal to group-based recognition which, in the long run, may work against equality.
The tenets of liberalism do not directly support women's emancipation such that it has been possible for liberal thinkers to oppose gender based equality.
Since the introduction of the framework in the 90s, feminism has become increasingly intersectional, giving a voice to the oppressed, including minorities and immigrants of all genders.
Non-Western women have had a massive role in the feminist movement.
Kamla Bhasin broke vast ground in promoting feminism in South Asia and was involved in changes to rape legislature in India.
A Brazilian woman, Bertha Lutz, was primarily responsible for bringing feminism to the UN.
The intersection of feminism and climate justice provides benefits for men and women alike, through initiatives to stem the consequences of climate change.
Ugandan women harmed by climate change have organised a movement to fight for more considerate policy and ensure women are protected.
Feminists do not inspire climate action; rather it has been a scientific concern for years, and a core issue for many.
There are entire movements dedicated specifically to climate feminism, demonstrating that feminism can also be a driving force behind climate action.
Feminism grew out of the Civil Rights movement; centering Black and brown women in feminist activism from early on.
Sojourner Truth preceded the Civil Rights movement and was undoubtedly a feminist activist, offering one of the first arguments that complicated theories of gender and the treatment of Black women.
Black women played an integral leadership role in the women's suffrage movement; yet, their contributions are rarely mentioned alongside their white feminist counterparts.
Historically, many women of colour found feminist talking points reductive, to the point of establishing parallel movements such as womanism.
Intersectional feminism promotes the welfare of non-white, non-heterosexual people over white, heterosexual men and women.

When integrated with activism, intersectionality enables people to centre minoritised communities in conversations, focusing on alleviating complex combinations of oppression - though this may seldom occur.

Intersectionality has only existed for 30 years. Yet, the welfare of white, heterosexual people has been the standard for the vast majority of human history; those that do not adhere to traditional norms deserve an equitable voice as well.

The concept of "whiteness" was first used to claim superiority of the "white race" in the 1600s when the British introduced the concept of racism to the Americas during the trans-Atlantic slave trade. Prior to that, intersectional thought would not have been necessary.
Various factions of feminism have previously attempted to deplatform and silence other women whose opinions they don't agree with, including others in the movement.
Sex workers are often excluded from feminist spaces.
Often feminists claim that enacting sex work negative legislature will protect the women working in the industry, despite persistent refutations of this claim (p. 2).
The feminist left is quite divided over sex work; some feminists find it acceptable, others question whether the women working in the industry have much of a choice.
Sex workers are more likely to be included in feminist spaces than patriarchal ones.
Evangelical women often simultaneously uphold the patriarchy and weaponise their gender to harm sex workers.
Sex workers are often presented in reductive and sexist ways in traditional media; feminist media is often more respectful.
Most of the countries that have legalized sex work have done so under the political leadership of men.
Trans-Exclusionary Radical Feminists (TERFs) limit discussion by gatekeeping feminist spaces, excluding trans and non-binary people.
Though TERFs claim that they are not trans-exclusionary, they problematically include trans men in their definition of a woman and propagate attitudes that cause harm.

TERFs have been physically violent towards trans women attending lesbian and bisexual visibility conferences and summits; this is a far more serious issue than the cancelled talks and beliefs they decry as harming feminism.
TERFs are a minority actively decried by many more progressive and younger feminist factions. Silencing within feminist movements is multidirectional and should not be attributed to a single group.
TERF academics in the UK have claimed that they were silenced for their "gender critical" beliefs, echoing a previous trend of no-platforming transphobic speakers by university student unions.

TERFs often appeal to right-wing fears of identity politics, and political correctness gone wrong; when progressives note that TERF views may be damaging (p. 692), TERFs assert their status as victims closing off conversation.
TERFs have protested, campaigned against, and doxxed other feminists, keeping them silent for fear of reprisal. Such actions, along with their relative power, are likely to do a lot of harm.
Pro-life women often find themselves excluded from mainstream feminist movements.
Pro-life feminist groups were denied partnerships with the Women's March on Washington 2017; several groups were rejected outright, and another that was initially approved was later removed.
Regardless of the official status or limited participation of pro-life feminist groups, thousands of pro-life women marched in Washington.
Pro-life women frequently find their voices crowded out of discussions regarding abortion and choose to avoid attending marches and similar types of events in protest.
Feminists fight for bodily autonomy; it is not in-fighting when one party acts directly counter to one of the major propositions of feminism.
It is inherently impossible to be both pro-life and a feminist; a lack of reproductive bodily autonomy subjugates women.
Feminism should be about the empowerment of all women, not only the power to end the lives of unborn babies.

Some intolerance is necessary in order to create a tolerant society; a group that sets no hard boundaries is likely to find itself undermined. As such, it is legitimate for feminists to occasionally deplatform others.
Deplatforming serves as a necessary means of curtailing dangerous speech outside of the use of state powers; it is the only middle ground that protects both individuals and civil liberties.

Many women in feminist movements lack the power to push back against others that would silence them were it not for deplatforming. The boundaries feminists set are protective and ultimately facilitate better conversations.
It is hypocritical for ostensibly open spaces to refuse entry to some based on their political views; such actions may have a greater chilling effect than any dissent that could otherwise occur.

The line between what is tolerable and what isn't may be incredibly difficult to discern, especially within an activist space that aims to consistently evolve in its approach. As such, deplatforming should not be allowed.
Some feminists advocate for activisms that allow open conversation, frame conflict (within reason) as productive, and push the movement forward.
Whilst historic feminists held highly problematic views, feminism has demonstrated its commitment to evolution and inclusion by distancing itself from these ideologies.

Some female figureheads are targeted by a limiting groupthink that attempts to cancel them prior to any direct conflict or dialogue. This indicates that on balance, feminists may not push for open conversation.
The voices and opinions of men, even those attempting to be allies, are often excluded from feminist discussions.
Some women have accused men of colonising feminism for their own ends, and advocate for their exclusion.
Instead of advocating for integrated spaces that enable all entrepreneurs to work together, some feminists have started women-only businesses and clubs.

Men who are encouraged to join feminism and treated as important actors for making change are more likely to report intent to act. This may inspire more long term inclusion and improve feminism (p. 2).
Those who believe men should be excluded from feminism are in the minority.
Some men believe that politically correct men and feminists have excluded them from conversations regarding mental health and well-being.

There are concerns from some men that boys now lack role-models in media, which may drive them to despair and crime. Current feminist trends preclude balanced representation, leaving men by the wayside.

Outreach for men's mental health happens in a wide variety of forms, sites, or campaigns, supporting them in a number of ways. This may attract less notice as it is not an incendiary talking point that drives attention.
Men, even allies, can sometimes make the mistake of fighting sexism on behalf of women, instead of alongside women - it is legitimate for feminists to push back against this (p. 646).
Some men could be considered a "woke misogynist," someone that labels themself a feminist without actually changing any behaviors to support the movement.
Some feminist allied men may follow a paternalistic instinct to protect women, paradoxically reinforcing gender stereotypes and sexism (p. 2).
Male feminists are often maligned and depicted as having ulterior motives for their political engagement; this limits discourse, and may be done disingenuously.
Men have thanked feminism for its help and joined the movement.
Feminist men and women are able to mutually support one another to create great progress; this is celebrated through events like International Men's Day.

A previous leader left the feminist movement to become a men's rights activist, eventually viewing women as the true controllers of society. This clearly demonstrates the extent to which feminism is alienating to men.
Feminism aims to correct the systemic biases against women and other minorities that are born out of historical discrimination.
Treatment and research for women's health issues are not prioritized as highly as those that are universal, or affect solely men.
Women are more likely to be diagnosed with a mental illness than men yet often do not receive adequate care.

Women are often dismissed as mentally ill when they present with physical symptoms; this drives up diagnosis rates for these illnesses, while also reducing the quality of healthcare that people receive.
The increased inclination to believe that women were mentally ill led doctors to prescribe them psychopharmaceuticals at high rates, increasing drug use in later generations (p. 241).
Sexism may worsen women's mental health, as they struggle with a socially pervasive loss of control.
Sensual or sexual stereotypes in advertising have negative effects on the mental health and self-confidence of girls and young women.
Despite gender stereotype bans in advertising in some parts of the world, young women are often harmed by online advertising (p. 4).
Sexism is often used to the detriment of women as it drives sales and engagement with products (p. 5). Through the normalization of photo editing, dysmorphic body ideals are often promoted.
Sex and sensuality is often reimagined in empowering ways that breakdown social stigma; this may subvert the previous harms of advertising.
Hostile sexism negatively effects men as well as women; it is likely that other factors contribute towards women's higher rates of mental illness.
Men are often considered to suffer from externalised mental health issues; yet, such a perspective may encourage men's mental health issues to be dismissed until they manifest stereotypically.
Suicide rates are often higher in men; poor risk communication may contribute to this, as men are left out of conversations on mental health and therefore struggle to identify warning signs.
Men's sexual and reproductive health needs are often prioritised over women's.
In order to address recurrent medical failures that perpetuated information asymmetries around women's experiences of the pill, women have started forums and crowdsourced data.
Medical implants for people with wombs, like the Dalkon shield and transvaginal meshes, are often underresearched and can have incredibly poor health outcomes for those outfitted with them.
Men's infertility is often ignored as reproduction is seen to be a woman's duty. This causes distress and hinders care.

Women, who often have wombs, are impractical to include in medical trials due to variations in their hormones throughout the menstrual cycle, though they are similar on average to men. This is why it appears as though there is a prioritisation of men's illness in research.
Women often experience mistreatment at the hands of medical practitioners, including having their privacy violated.
Though responses to women's pain vary in Western medicine - from the view that Black women do not feel pain, to assuming that others are hysterical - the end result is often poor care.
Various medical phenomena, like the husband stitch or symphisiotomies, show the scant disregard some doctors and institutions have for people in labour.

Abuse from medical practitioners is not exclusive to women (p. 3). Rather, because the medical system is regulatory by nature, it influences everyone and particularly harms the "deviant" by stripping them of autonomy (pp. 23-24). It is reductive to remove men from this conversation.
Despite their shorter life span, men's health is often underdiscussed.
Men are known to avoid seeking help due to issues in medical training and social norms (p. 1058), yet service delivery remains mostly umchanged (p. 146).

Men are more prone to social isolation which decreases the quality of their health. Despite this, men are often deterred from seeking help, something neither health campaigns nor feminists effectively combat.
Men often engage in self-surveillance to identify issues prior to seeking healthcare, yet appropriate risk communication that encourages and scaffolds this process is limited (p. 9).
Given the disproportionate effort many women expend managing men's emotions, it is unclear why feminists should focus on men's social isolation at the expense of helping other groups.
Men are often encouraged to isolate themselves and limit their efforts in friendships to avoid homophobic stereotypes. These attitudes are actively campaigned against by feminists.
Men receive disproportionately more healthcare funding compared to women - though they are not discussed, they are researched (p. 956).
As men historically were viewed as the default, and women as deviant, feminists must prioritise campaigning for women's research needs if they wish to make change.
Major campaigns, like Movember, decrease the stigma of poor health amongst men and raise awareness of potentially lethal illnesses.
Breast cancer receives both more research funding and greater media awareness than prostate cancer, despite a similar number of victims affected by each.
In the UK, men have a higher risk of developing prostate cancer than women do of developing breast cancer.

While the risk for developing prostate cancer is higher, breast cancer has a more destructive effect on an individual, with early detection increasing the chance of survival. This may explain the discrepancy in both research and awareness funding.
Campaigns for breast cancer are generally more successful and generate more activity than those for prostate cancer.
It is easier to develop empathy and awareness for breast cancer, as the breast is an external organ, whereas the ovaries and prostate are internal organs and inherently "invisible" (p. 27).

The finite resources available to various cancer campaigns are typically consumed by the first mover. As Breast Cancer Awareness Month began in 1985, and Movember in 2003, it makes sense that the former is more successful.
The lack of social media engagement and support behind prostate cancer awareness may stem from men's refusal to discuss their health issues for fear of appearing weak - a typically 'feminine' trait.
With the exception of Twitter, the majority of users on major social media websites are women. This may limit men's ability to share vulnerable posts.
Healthcare interventions often do not take into account the positive attributes of masculine identity and therefore can cause more harm (p. 1).
Marketing campaigns for breast cancer awareness could encourage behaviors that increase the risk of developing breast cancer.
Airlines frequently participate in Breast Cancer Awareness Month; yet, frequent flying is one of the major risk factors for developing breast cancer.
Women flight attendants were found to be 50% more likely to develop breast cancer than women from the overall population.

Many alcohol brands have been known to adorn their products with pink ribbons, promising to donate portions of the proceeds of the sales of these goods, despite the fact that alcohol consumption is one of the risk factors for developing breast cancer (p. 26).

Despite being somewhat hypocritical, it is better for companies with goods or services that increase the risk of developing breast cancer to create campaigns to raise some awareness and potentially save some lives from the disease than do nothing at all.
Ovarian cancer receives less funding than breast cancer; it is unlikely that discrepancies in cancer research funding come from a preference of women to men, but rather the social role of the breast.
Breast cancer is not exclusive to cisgender women.
Transgender AMAB individuals undergoing hormone therapy have a higher risk of developing breast cancer than their cisgender male counterparts.
Breast cancer affects men.
With fewer ducts and lobules in the male breast for cancer cells to metastasize, men comprise just 1% of breast cancer cases.
The risk of a man developing breast cancer in the UK is nearly negligible.
In the US, 100+ male infants die each year due to circumcision, yet some feminists disregard male genital mutilation.
Feminists may disregard circumcision as a site for advocacy due to the normalisation of the practice, regardless of the associated harms.

Whilst death due to circumcision could occur, it is exceptionally unlikely. Compared to FGM - which has a higher death toll due to complications in the original surgery and in childbirth (p. 4) - it is not a problem.
Feminists fight to protect women from gendered violence, sexual assault, and harassment.
The way in which women are presented in advertisements can entrench the notion of their existence being for the use of men, normalising gendered objectification, harassment and violence.
Latent sexism in print media adverts may encourage support for heinous acts against women (p. 7).
Nudity in advertising in Europe heavily features sexualized images of women, encouraging objectification that may contribute to recurrent sexism.
Some nations have banned gender stereotyping in ads and censored sexual imagery. Sexist advertising may diminish as nations set a precedent for respectful advertising.

Thirty-five percent of women worldwide have experienced either physical and/or sexual intimate partner violence or sexual violence by a non-partner at some point in their lives. Feminism can help combat this by changing social norms.
Refuge shelters have feminist origins. Feminists worked to make a space for women as they were, and still are, overwhelmingly more likely to be victimised by their partners than vice versa.

Feminist theorists, like MacKinnon, have problematised the idea of a private/public life distinction to call attention to the harms women can experience in the home, opening new space for policy making and discussion (p. 4).
Women report higher rates of perpetuating intimate partner violence than men, and men report higher rates of experiencing this violence. Feminism leaves out some victims by emphasising women (p. 2).
Seventy percent of women who claim to have been sexually assaulted in the workplace did not report it.

Feminist activism, in particular the #MeToo movement, has been criticized for creating an anti-men bias in legal systems. Critics say this may harm due process, and encourage people to assume the guilt of the accused.
Many celebrities, business leaders and media personalities have lost jobs over accusations that could be not substantiated and brought to civil or criminal court.
A bias is formed when you become influenced by statistics or narratives rather than the facts of a case; feminism encourages this with the shift to believing all victims.
Due process is not controlled by citizens, but rather is influenced by policing culture and other incentives, which feminists may struggle to influence.

There are few examples, if any, of men who are not provided legal due process. Most reported claims of sexual crimes do not receive convictions, suggesting that the legal system has a bias that favors men.

Abuse of due process due to policing culture can be seen in the Duke false allegation case. The DA abused his position of power and pursued the case, likely because he was up for re-election. Feminists could not influence this.
Anti-men bias does not exist if the claims are true. Men are statistically more likely to be sexual predators, and women are statistically more likely to be the victims.
Women often fear for their safety when rejecting romantic interest from male strangers, given the risk that they could be harmed.
Image based sexual abuse is more likely to harm women than men, due to deeply gendered moral ideas of sex (p. 2).
Statistics may neither prove nor disprove a bias, as they can be heavily influenced by existing biases.
Social expectations and understanding of coercion may contribute to a significant undercounting of female sexual predators.
Some feminists have opted to use the legal system to reduce harassment, which increases incarceration without necessarily addressing the root of the issue.
State intervention approaches to domestic violence often perpetuate binaries, enforcing Western perspectives (p. 341). This is problematic, insofar as these are widely spread and shape policy.
Feminists may lean into tough on crime narratives in order to ensure that sexual assault is taken seriously; this intersects with racist narratives of criminality to devastating effect.

Within rape culture, women are held to an impossible standard, and denied justice. By using existing systems, feminism can make some headway against this injustice, instead of waiting for societal attitudes to shift.
Many US states have laws that do not work with modern understandings of consent. These deny justice to victims - most of whom are women - and as such are necessary for feminists to campaign against.
Girls are often hypersexualized and grow up feeling scared and insecure due to harassment (p. 12). Feminists need to act quickly to break this generational cycle which legal systems facilitate.

Street harassment does not necessarily stem from misogyny, but powerlessness. As feminism aims to reduce the former and not the latter, the problem will remain - albeit with a different victim profile.

Social attitudes that contribute to harm against women often come from normalised violence within society at large (p. 3). By focusing solely on women, feminists do not tackle the source of the issue so it may continue.
Though prisons have negative side-effects, it is important that feminists weaponise a respected system to ensure that people think their issues are legitimate and require action.
Given that feminists can work to reform law enforcement and reduce sexism and other discrimination, it is not legitimate to deny people justice by claiming the system is beyond repair.

Carceral approaches to justice often perpetuate harms against minoritised groups, increasing their alienation. This does not remediate the issues it claims to, and may make things worse in the long term.
Some feminisms fail to reconcile progressive activism with misogynistic practices in some religions and cultures.
Some feminists claim that Islam is compatible with liberatory thinking, yet the two contradict each other. Ignorance of this repression is illegitimate and causes harm.
Some feminists fail to support Muslim women who refuse to wear the veil, for fear of being branded Islamophobic.
Denigrations of Islam as anti-feminist are often based in reductive perceptions of hijabi autonomy.
Islamic feminists find that their faith empowers their politics. By claiming that feminism and Islam are incompatible, these women are harmed.
Religion has historically been leveraged to achieve the emancipation of women in some places; feminists can emulate this to empower liberatory sects.
Feminists have campaigned for the inclusion of female priests. Women are currently excluded from this crucial ecumenical role in many branches of Christianity, serving only in lower status positions.
Feminism undermines the value of meritocracy, which is an important aspect of equality that is universally accessible. Through this subversion, feminism makes the world worse.
People often prefer just societies to equal ones; when feminists fail to recognise that people work hard and should be rewarded for it, they damage their movement.

Equality, unlike equity, implies a lack of recognition of natural or developed differences between individuals. This lack of recognition could have negative results, and as such feminists should not seek equality.
Feminism may encourage a focus on identity over other efforts - this undermines the importance of hard work and positive actions.
Preferences are malleable and affected by a number of factors. It is reductive to limit just action to preserve current ideals (p. 20).
Though feminism may suffer from undermining meritocracy myths in the short term, they make considerably more change in the long term than they would through acquiescence.
Some feminists advocate for positive discrimination; those policies may be ineffective and defeat the point of having a movement for equality.
People may prefer to be acknowledged as individuals instead of being defined by their gender identity; quotas may be essentialising (p. 22).
Gender quotas that aim to achieve equality may yield counterproductive results.
People often perceive quotas for women to be particularly unfair compared to those for men. Therefore, shocks to unconscious biases may not accrue, and negative perceptions of women may persist.

Habitual discrimination against women often goes unremarked upon, and requires quotas to call attention to. This is worth any pushback that the policy receives, as more women may join politics in the long term.
Political quotas can increase the quality of the candidate pool (p. 1).
Discrimination is never justified.
People do not choose their identities, and as such should not be held accountable for making social change.
Quotas reduce people to numbers, restricting their opportunities and disregarding their skillsets and aspirations when it comes to work.
Corrective discrimination is justified, insofar as it rectifies historic harms that arise from an initial act of injustice.
Quotas have helped tens of thousands of Afro-Brazilians attend university in Brazil (pp. 172-173).
There is no feminist consensus on the implementation of quotas, as some fear that they are used to create a more palatable political apparatus without structural change (p. 348).
Quotas that tackle women's under-representation in government are vital for ensuring effective and inclusive law-making.
Research indicates that female politicians increase policy-making that emphasises quality of life and reflects the priorities of families, women, and ethnic, and racial minorities.
Nations led by women handled the COVID-19 pandemic more effectively than the ones led by men.
All-women shortlists are undemocratic and do more harm than good.

In some areas, left-wing voters are more likely to vote for women. By creating all-women short lists, right wing candidates may find that their politicians do not accurately reflect their values (p. 16).
All-women shortlists may separate politicians elected from the lists and those who are not. This may be used to attack women's merit and legitimacy as policy makers.
Democracy is preserved, even with all-women shortlists, as individual is free to vote for the candidates of their choice at the ballot box.
Party candidate selection processes are typically undemocratic, as parties are free to choose the candidates they want, like any organisation.
Rwanda has made huge strides toward gender parity in governance, potentially creating space for long term improvements to their democratic participation (p. 362).
Meritocracy is only valuable when everyone competes from an equal starting point; as society finds women less persuasive based on arbitrary characteristics, feminism is necessary (p. 2698).
Feminists tackle perception gaps in AI by noting the ways in which translation apps perpetuate stratification of roles, and hiring discrimination. This activism facilitates true meritocracy.
Women are systemically excluded from positions of power by norms which demean ambitious women, create inhospitable workplaces, and worsen socio-economic inequalities.
Not all biases are bad, as men and women are different. This means that differences in perception are legitimate, and feminists are wrong to seek equality.

There are physiological and psychological differences between men and women which justify their different positions in society. These biases are not bad, and are illegitimate for feminists to disregard.
Women are closer in terms of their DNA to chimpanzees than to human men.
Different evaluations of the genetic difference between men and women narrow the gap to a 1% divergence.
The suggested genetic similarity between women and chimps is discounted by many scientists as only one gene is involved.
Men and women often have differences in their brain size and structures; by ignoring these physiological disparities, people may not be usefully nudged to areas where they are more skilled.
The alleged differences between men and women are often examined without holistic evaluation of their context (p. 1). This is reductive and ignores the ways in which society creates differences.
Viewing gender or sex as a binary is outdated, rendering debates on the dichotomy of men and women unnuanced.
Biases are often justified using incorrect or limited recollections of the past, in order to perpetuate ideas of difference. These are illegitimate and must be corrected.
Feminists rectify a perspective gap when they note that a woman is the first to do something, as women are often written out of history, or actively discriminated against.
Patriarchal bias may lead people to rely on history to justify sexism. Yet the past needn't define the future of society, particularly if it allows the world to remain unjust.
Feminism has helped minority women less often than white women.
White feminists often leverage their race to emphasise the importance of their victimhood; this can lead to myopic lobbying with negative effects for others.

White women, in places like the US and the UK, simultaneously denigrated and homogenised the enslaved whilst co-opting their suffering. When feminists do not confront this practice they may allow it to continue.

Significant work is done by modern activists to undermine reductive or lazy approaches to feminism; as such, it is erroneous to consider white feminisms to be the sole narrative force of the movement.
Aligning ineffective feminisms with a particular race or social group can hamper activists looking to expand conversations of harm - playing into the patriarchy's hands.
The intersectional invisibility of Black women has marginalized their existence and excluded them from feminist movements.
Black women are systematically excluded from leadership roles in modern feminist organizations.
BIWOC (Black, Indigenous, and Women of Color) are often excluded from critical comemorative events (p. 11).

Black women, excluded from leadership roles, are often called on en masse to "save the day." Viewing them as an afterthought could have been avoided had they been invited to positions of power from the start.
Black women in the US currently lead vital progressive movements that, if successful, will help many people.
Black women took the initiative to create their own organizations, creating opportunities to better advocate for their rights.
Black women were forced to create their own organizations due to a lack of opportunities in the traditional, white-focused ones.

Very little research about Black views on feminism has been conducted, actively demonstrating feminist academics' ignorance to the nuanced views of Black women on the subject. This may have hampered their activism.
Black feminist organizations are critically underfunded.
The amount of help provided by feminist movements can only be subjectively evaluated; some would argue that Black women have been helped by feminism, and not actively harmed.
Western feminists often engage in colonial statecraft to the active detriment of women in other nations.

The birth of the modern feminist movement was rooted in white women voicing their opinions and making demands to shape policies to help other white women; the achievements, needs, and desires of minorities were often ignored.
Western feminists often hold reductive and dangerously binaristic ideals that associate the West with development and liberation, obfuscating histories of gender equality in other nations (p. 2).
In France, Burqa bans are often legitimised through appeals to feminism, despite the fact that they restrict women's choices and perpetuate racism.
While feminism in the West has a racist history, great strides are being made to decolonise, radicalise, and nuance modern day feminisms.

Previously regressive teen girl magazines have become radically feminist and adopted many intersectional stances. This educates younger generations and is likely to ensure that feminist movements continue to improve.
Increasingly, anti-racist views are being platformed. This may erode the liberal assumptions of mainstream feminisms to create a better and more sensitive movement.
Rising transphobia from some feminists can fuel anti-Black policy making, particularly in sports.

While mainstream feminisms may be reductive, there has always been pushback against these approaches in the form of decolonial feminism. This approach is now being adopted more widely, giving a broader perspective on many issues.
Feminist movements in Asia are highly inclusive and growing in strength; such advances are likely to help women of many races.
Women in Myanmar stand as role models in their fight to preserve democracy and achieve gender equality.
Asian feminists have pushed for expansions of their role into foreign policy, which is likely to have great dividends in the future as diplomacy is bolstered.
In places like South Korea, traditional values are seen as diametrically opposed to women's liberation; the movement may be unable to circumvent this.
Chinese feminists may find themselves censored; this stifles activism and may have negative outcomes for the women themselves.

Women have become less happy as they have experienced an increase in rights and access to the workforce - in part tied to the rise of feminist action (p. 3). As such, the policies feminists support are not conducive to a better society.

Part of the decrease in women's happiness may stem from feminists shaming traditional women. These women are often seen as counter to the movement and are pressured to adopt different ideals and behaviors.
Feminism can put unrealistic pressure on women to succeed. Some may feel that their life does not measure up to the movement's ethos and feel dejected.
Some of the unhappiness women experience may stem from anti-feminist backlash. This indicates the continued necessity to push for social progress (p.703).
Whilst some feminists may be dogmatic, others are open to supportive discussions of traditional values and the influences of choice in modernity. It is reductive to presume otherwise.
Feminism may struggle to make change as it promotes anti-family policies and perspectives. These are legitimised by claiming that marriage and child-rearing are patriarchal.
Political lesbianism encouraged women to actively disavow people they loved in order to subvert the patriarchy. This approach denigrated women's choices and was likely alienating.
Some feminists believe women should work and take up the fight for equality - instead of getting married, and raising kids - as they do not believe it is possible, or desirable, to do both.
Some feminists have suggested that stay-at-home mothering should be illegal, directly countering the principles of free choice that feminism espouses.
Popular media outlet, Everyday Feminism, promotes that stay at home moms should be supported by feminism.
Feminists are not anti-family as that would defy their ethos of gender equality; rather their policies expand freedoms to benefit many, including families.

Feminists do not disavow family, marriage, or traditional house-keeping as a rule; rather they disavow the systems involved in each of these that denigrate women's work and restrict their choices (pp. 76-77).

Women often feel pressure to have children, despite having other priorities. When feminism celebrates alternative forms of the good life - career based or otherwise - these women may feel as if they have more support.
Correlation is not causation; there is no reason to believe that the rise in feminist activity caused a decrease in women's happiness.

Women may no longer feel pressure to feign happiness, due to feminism (p. 28). This increase in honesty makes it more possible to craft useful social policy, as there is more information on women's true preferences and needs.
Women are often stressed about balancing family and career, as men do not share equally in household responsibilities. It is not choice that causes women stress, but patriarchy.
Women now have to choose between having a family, their career, or balancing both - which can be challenging to manage. Feminism did not improve their quality of life by encouraging this dilemma.
Feminism helps to challenge and dismantle sexist stereotypes reducing epistemic injustices (p. 1). By correcting hidden differences in perceptions, equality is furthered.
Femininity is typically seen as weaker and inferior to masculinity; various feminisms aim to subvert this by supporting all forms of gender expression.
Misogynistic language is still persistently used in society, normalising the degradation of women.
Misogynistic microaggressions are so prevalent in daily language that women may not consciously notice them.
Women still battle with bias in language, as femininity is considered weak.
As language shapes our perceptions of the world, microaggressions dismiss women by belittling and excluding them.
Though they may be imprecise mediation tools, bias reporting systems in workplaces and universities may help to address microaggressions, reducing their social impact.
A report found more than six million instances of the words slut or whore written on Twitter in a year, 20% of which appeared to be threatening (pp. 9-10).
Some political systems have begun to agitate for gender fair language change; this may help to reduce societal sexism with time (p. 2).
As women are more likely to use misogynistic language, verbal or written abuse is often not addressed by feminism directly.

Women's use of misogynistic language is born out of the patriarchal standard of seeing women as inferior to men and viewing other women as competition. Despite being a seemingly perfect site for feminist activism, it is not an area of focus.
Feminism acknowledges women's sexist language and behaviours, by highlighting issues such as "horizontal hostility" (p. 537).

On social media, women tend to favour derogatory name-calling while men make personal comments about a woman's appearance, intelligence, and sexuality. The latter implies a deep-seated hatred which may attract feminist focus, even though men are not the sole perpetrators of online misogyny.
Some feminists stigmatise masculinity, though this can be harmful and misdirects attention from other causes of social issues.
Presuming men to be violent or poor fathers stigmatises them and causes negative psychological responses (p. 1118); yet some feminists push to undermine men's social role.
Transmasc feminists offer new visions of masculinity that can both push back against traditional forms of the gender role and reduce stigma.
Feminists often inspire men through strong leadership; this may counterbalance other negative discourses.
Over-gendered and sexualised representation in media and marketing degrades women and presents them with harmful, unattainable standards.
The societal critique of women's bodies and belief that they must be attractive or thin to be worthy of success can lead to self-harm and disordered eating in women and girls.
Research has shown that judgements regarding a woman's appearance and weight directly impact her likelihood of being hired for a job.
Women are 16 times more likely than their male counterparts to report being discriminated against on the basis of their weight in hiring practices and at work.
Many women in high-achieving fields feel an internal pressure to be thin in order to be successful, fuelling negative thought processes.
The majority of people with eating disorders are women (p. 2).
A growing awareness of unachievable body norms is already beginning to create a societal shift as more and more women shun diet culture.
Companies like Dove and American Eagle have adapted their marketing campaigns by using real women instead of professional models, reflecting the societal shift against diet culture.
Movements like body positivity and self-acceptance can help to counter negative self-image, undermining social perceptions.
Feminists are actively trying to adapt and improve the video game industry and surrounding culture which is often accused of being misogynistic.
Videos games often feature women as passive decorations, objectifying them (p. 1).
As players often strongly identify with the characters they play, women's exclusion or passivity in video games is troubling, and perpetuates a perspective gap (p. 11).
The depiction of women in video games has negative ramifications for women's self-esteem, and men's perception of them. This should be fixed rapidly to reduce harm.
Major videogames, such as Fortnite, are attempting to be more diverse in their character options.
Many popular video games focus on historical conquests, sieges, and warfare; it would be an inaccuracy to predominantly feature women in these types of games.
Often women were excluded from warfare to the extent that they had to present as men to fight.
Women often filled gendered roles in historic warfare; whilst these actions were incredibly useful, they may not offer the typical drama and intrigue of video games.
Women participated in historical conquest, sieges, and warfare, as well as piracy. Their exclusion in media perpetuates historic bias.

Two of the three most popular characters in the Assassin's Creed video game series, one of the most popular in the world, are women. Given the violent, in-your-face, historical nature of the game, these starring roles are anything but passive.

The top five most popular video games of all time were fantasy-style games. These could have easily featured a woman as the main character as historic accuracy was not a factor in their creation; yet, only one did so.
Women are underrepresented as video game main characters, despite both making up a large proportion of players and being vocally critical of this asymmetric representation.
Zelda, arguably one of the most famous video game characters of all time, was an inspiring warrior princess.
Video games may encourage inappropriate sexual behaviour (p. 77).
Feminists who attempt to change inappropriate sexual behavior in gaming communities are often met with threats and resistance.

The stylisation of women in video games is a legitimate artistic choice, akin to the hypermasculinity and muscular structure of the men. Only decrying women's depictions as sexist precludes meaningful conversation and exposes hypocrisy.
All forms of media feature some level of misrepresentation, it is unfair to target video games as being unique in this regard.
Men are degraded and sexualised in adverts aimed at women; feminists sometimes represent this as an exclusively female issue and therefore may lose support for their movement.
The objectification of men is a growing problem, yet feminists often do not call attention to the double standard.
The sexual objectification of men does not have the same impact on them as objectification does on women.
The objectification of women often leads them to be seen as less moral, and unintelligent (p. 1).

Blonde women are more likely to be sexually objectified than brunettes, experiencing increased attention and harassment from strangers. They are also likely to face stereotypes that demean their intelligence.
Stereotypes regarding blondes, intelligence, and sexual promiscuity originated around 250 years ago and have persisted ever since.

Viewing women as less intelligent when objectifying them may arise from categorising them as emotional beings instead of agential ones. This increases protective instincts which may be useful in some instances.

Men are not objectified in the same way as women as their objectification is often homoerotic and celebratory in nature; it does not strip them of their humanity or degrade them like the typical male gaze.
Though men and women both experience negative pressures from porn, only women are reduced to objects. Men are more likely to experience penis-related shame or self-consciousness.
Psychologists believe that objectifying men is harmful and leads to negative imaging, low self-worth, and stereotyping.
Men feel degraded and become dissatisfied with their bodies as a result of seeing muscular male models in magazines and on TV.
The Adonis complex has become more prevalent with the rise of social media, and yet often goes unremarked upon within eating disorder and health discourses.
Many women prefer less muscular men than are presented in the media, and therefore are unlikely to be driving the pressure for men to bulk up.
The proportion of men being sexualized is much lower than that of women.
Many countries and regulatory authorities address sexism in advertising, which is attempting to reduce the frequency of women being represented sexually in the media (pp. 66-67).
Despite efforts to censor sexism, sexual advertising in magazines has increased over the last 30 years.
Even brands whose primary customer base is women, like Victoria's Secret, sexualize women in their advertising. Given this, such representation may not be seen as degrading but rather laudable.
Brands that market towards cishet women may exploit the internalised male gaze and encourage women to play into their objectification as part of the fulfillment of womanhood.

Part of the reason Victoria's Secret was founded was to help men feel more comfortable shopping for lingerie for their significant other. Their advertising therefore may not actually directly target women.

Victoria's Secret's original brand design was geared towards attracting men to their stores. However, the company has consistently struggled to keep sales up, suggesting that the trade-off of women's comfort for the male gaze was not profitable.

In 2021, Victoria's Secret changed their marketing strategies and announced that they will swap the angels for "what women want." This indicates that prior sexualised strategies were poorly received by the target audience.
Throughout history, men have often been considered the default producers of creative arts; this has facilitated the exclusion of women from discussions of humanity and perspective.
Despite a higher degree of originality, women's creativity is often dismissed in favour of presuming that men are more musical.
There are a number of examples of men taking credit for artwork, sculptures, and architectural renderings created by women, putting themselves in the spotlight unduly.
Mary Shelley's husband was credited with penning Frankenstein, after she published the book anonymously.
The true creator of the fountain attributed to Marcel Duchamp, Baroness Elsa von Freytag-Loringhoven, has not been fully credited and centered within discussions of the ground-breaking art piece.

Some women prefer to sit in the background and guide the careers of those in their life - such actions may indicate a dispreference for the spotlight. This can allow men to take centre stage artistically.
Men no longer hold a place of great power in publishing, often falling by the wayside for women; given this, their position as a default may have only been fleeting.
Historically, men were the major producers of art, due to limited social acceptance of women working as artists.
Some female authors did not help the presumption that men are the default creators of art by taking masculine pseudonyms to succeed.
As strict gender roles are decreasingly likely to be supported and enforced in Western society, tackling sexist stereotypes is only marginally beneficial (p. 1).
Men and women are equally able to stay home and raise children demonstrating more fluid gender roles and a decreased need for feminist influence.
Men have been able to redefine masculinity as stay-at-home-fathers.
Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, men were increasingly likely to stay home and take care of their children.
Due to gender stereotypes, women do a greater share of parenting and household duties. These jobs are not remunerated and impede women's career advancement.
New mothers allocate twice as much of their time to child care activities than fathers (p. 11).
Studies varying in the diversity and number of nations involved indicate that women do more household chores than the men in their household.
Gendered divisions in parenting duties are in large part due to biological differences and preferences.
In chimpanzees the male does negligible parental care (p. 6868).
Modern societies have developed to a level of sophistication that is able to override historical biological and physiological traits for the good of societal functioning and liberalism.
Society looks down on women who are not married with children by the age of 30; whereas, men are often able to wait and marry at an older age.
When parenting, fathers are often applauded for doing the bare minimum, whereas mothers are penalised for minor infractions.
With increasing maternal age, chromosomal abnormalities increase. It is not recommended for women to wait to have a child. This increases the pressure to have a child when young.
As women hit menopause at around 50 years of age, it is natural that women experience pressure to settle down and have a family.
People are increasingly free to seek whatever employment and educational opportunities they deem fit.
Though there is some lag in abolishing gender stereotypes, men are increasingly finding work in traditionally women-dominated roles.
The internet has greatly increased access to learning resources for all, democratising education though MOOCS, the video essay, and more.
Archaic, oftentimes sexist, laws keep women from being able to take advantage of the same economic opportunities as men, including dangerous and low-status jobs.
Women need permission from a male relative to work in 18 countries.
Women are not legally allowed to work at night in 29 countries.
Since the Maputo Protocol was signed in 2003, countries have been steadily improving their standing with regards to improving opportunities for women in the workplace (p. 1).
Women's behaviour continues to be held against a standard dictated by gender differentiation - this is seldom fair.
Women face double-standards for their sexual behaviour (p. 179).
A man with many sexual partners is often unremarked upon or celebrated, while society ostracises women for exhibiting the same behaviour (p. 1).
Women who have casual sex are often considered by their peers to have low self-esteem despite this being counter to reality; men are not judged in the same manner.
Women may be more likely to report sexual fluidity than men because of increased comfort in LGBT+ roles.

If women are outspoken or loud, especially in careers dominated by men, they are ridiculed and called bossy, disrespectful, or unfeminine. This perpetuates stereotypes and subtly deters women from expressing their opinions.

Subtle discrimination can often be battled through exposure to others breaking stereotypes, and being encouraged to engage with them actively. This is likely to reduce any lingering sexism such that it is not long term.
If a man wears feminine clothing he may be seen as deviant or weak; dress codes reinforce this.
Dress codes are often enforced in ways that shame men for wearing feminine clothing and frame their actions as untoward or dangerous.
Men have limited options to comply with gendered dress codes, at strict workplaces, which feminism attempts to address.
Gendered dress codes make members of the LGTBQ+ community uncomfortable (p. 15); feminist campaigns to change dress codes are beneficial to them.

In Europe, some men and boys have opted to wear skirts in protest against sexist dress codes that forbade them from wearing shorts in extremely hot temperatures. They would not take such action, if they supported the equivocation of skirts with weakness.
Men wearing skirts has become increasingly normalised by new fashion trends; this may help reduce stigma with time.
Some men deliberately wear high heels and skirts everyday to demonstrate the double standard between dress codes for men and women and that "clothes have no gender."
Some feminisms see women only as a group, and do not respect individuals' freedoms.

Since some colours, patterns, and forms of clothing are synonymous with 'traditional' feminine traits and gender roles, women who don them are often criticised by their peers for not being 'feminist' or 'feminist' enough.
Some parents believe they've failed at promoting feminism if their daughters still want to wear pink.
Post-WWII propaganda designed to get women back into the home and out of men's jobs spread the idea of pink, shiny, and floral decor as indicators of femininity and the female ideal.
Feminists have often criticised beauty standards and women's drive to attain them without offering meaningful alternatives for fulfilling those desires.

Many trailblazing women fear being named 'bad feminists;' yet, in speaking about their anxieties, they make it easier to discuss the nuances of feminism and the impulses that lead the movement to internal conflict.

Though criticisms of others as being 'not feminist enough' or 'bad feminists' are recurrent, such ideas are internally resisted which gives people the freedom to choose the appearance of their ideal feminism.
Some women may not want what feminism strives for.
Some women have left feminist movements because they found it highly alienating on a class basis.
Some women may buy into the idea that feminists are authoritarian and undermine women's freedom to choose their optimal lifestyle.
Some feminists criticise plastic surgery and denigrate it as repressive - a view that frames women as dupes incapable of sensibly negotiating power structures and their own liberation.
Some American women may have joined anti-feminist movements as they felt that women's liberation movements undermined their role as housewives and the respect they garned there.
Feminists often expand choice through campaigns for reproductive justice; these activisms reduce the coercive power of patriarchy and support women in making a number of choices.
Some women believe that feminism can promote negative views of men and can foster insecurity in young boys.
The increased tendency for people to see feminism as a brand rather than a political activist movement may enforce the correlation of feminism with misandry.
Insecurities in boys and men have always existed, feminism has changed the way they behave and become an easy scapegoat.

The women's suffrage movement, which helped them earn the right to vote, has given women the opportunity to decide elections. This is particularly true in places where women are more likely to both register and turn up to vote in high numbers.
Not all women supported suffrage, some actively campaigned against the right to vote for women.
People often attack a strawman of feminist activism instead of engaging with the real ideals of the movement.
Libertarianism is often closely aligned with feminist principles, as such respect for an individual's freedoms are baked into some aspects of feminist theory.

Libertarian feminists emphasize the freedom of the individual over ideas of a collective good; this has helped to steer feminist theories away from the state in some instances, viewing it as a restrictive and patriarchal operator.

Libertarianism can often facilitate selfish thinking that gives rise to 'choice' or 'lipstick' feminism; it is better to think of how to create a just system for all than how to make the world better for yourself (p. 176).
Given women cannot be truly free until womanhood is no longer a salient influence on their quality of life and choices, it is good that feminists treat womanhood as a unifying group identity.

Feminist phenomenological approaches are necessary to examine gender - they encourage people to consider the subtle inhibiting factors that limit their capacity for free choice, and make gender less restrictive in the long term.
Given gender identity is arbitrary and may not have any real value to some women, it is illegitimate for them to be instrumentalised by the feminist movement for others' gain.
Feminism's propensity to point out sexism where it does not exist eclipses other sociocultural issues.

An egalitarian approach may be more useful than a feminist one, as it does not immediately discern between the groups it attempts to help. This approach ensures that incendiary stances are less viable, as there is an emphasis on coalition building.

Though it lacks an activist past, egalitarianism is embedded in history. This may make it more effective at inspiring change, as it both lacks the negative associations of feminism and has been accepted in many places.
Religions, like Sikhism, Christianity, and Judaism, often have egalitarian interpretations; these could be co-opted by egalitarians to encourage change, even in a secular society.

The English Magna Carta in 1689, the US Constitution, and the French Constitution of 1958 are all based on egalitarian principles. By emphasising these ideals and playing into nationalist sympathies, egalitarians may inspire change.
Despite an ostensibly egalitarian bill of rights, in the UK, only 58% of the male population, and no women, could vote prior to 1918. Egalitarian ideals can often be cosmetic and ineffective.
Women's position in society has improved such that feminism is no longer a useful tool for analysing oppression. Feminists therefore take vital airtime from other activists.
People mostly believe that men and women are equally capable and support progress for gender equality. Feminist activism therefore has little left to do.
Gender parity is a UN millenium development goal, facilitated by a number of different charities and organisations.
In some places, like the UK, women make up a majority of the electorate. As such, they are likely to steer policy making in the direction of gender parity.
Only around 40% of men in the US identify as feminists. This is likely to limit alignment with feminist policies, even if they generally support gender parity.
Unconscious bias often shapes perceptions in ways that people find difficult to deconstruct. As such, men and women are often stereotyped into limiting roles, though people consciously support this.
Feminists fight to advance and defend women's rights.
There are only ten countries, worldwide, where women have equal legal rights to men.
The Marea Verde movement in South America fights a number of legal battles to expand women's bodily autonomy across the continent.
North African feminists have secured a number of legal rights including raising the minimum age for marriage, and expanding divorce access.
The US' Civil Rights Act and Title IX outlaw discriminating against a person based on their sex or gender.
Increasingly, nations are implementing legislature that protects women and girls.
Seeking to help women without examining their position or role in society can often lead to weak and tokenistic change that does nothing to change oppressive systems of power.
Mainstream feminisms emphasise identity, taking attention away from structural economic decline. This limits progress.

Companies can drive social change yet often only act when their bottom line is harmed. While feminists can change social norms, this does not stop economic systems from prioritising profit over people; as such, feminism is not as useful as other alternatives.
Gender roles contribute to inequality and can reduce women's earnings throughout their lifetimes; focusing on inequality instead of the root cause makes no difference.
Even when in similar roles, women are more likely to suffer from job insecurity than men (p. 1). Feminist thinking is a useful method to remain cognisant of this difference.
Due to historic discrimination, women are more likely to work precarious jobs than men (p. 5). This is an important aspect of economic inequality that feminism can target.
By discussing precarious work in terms of gender and wage gaps, feminists may lead people away from overall system reform.
Feminism has restructured systems of capital, in order to give women more financial autonomy. This demonstrates its power to effect economic systems.
Up until relatively recently, inheritance in Europe was passed to the eldest male heir under a system known as primogeniture. Feminists are pushing to entrench this change (p. 1).
Egalitarianism may be unfocussed, and therefore blind to the ways in which gender shapes the treatment of people. Without a movement to address gendered disparities, they could be ignored.
Women have historically been regarded as an object of exchange between men. If women didn't organise around gender, it would be difficult to make changes to these systems.
It is unclear why womanhood is a unique aspect of identity that could not be covered by race or class sensitive approaches.

Women are now increasingly able to climb to the top of society, due to the changes that feminism has driven. This campaigning is necessary to reduce sexism, as is borne out by the changes feminists have made.
Feminist support enables and empowers female politicians to be more effective, improving life for many women.
Boston elected its first woman of color as mayor, mainly through the support of the progressive feminist movement. Her policies may greatly improve life for Bostonians.
Empowering women to take political roles may make societies more caring and healthier.
Female politicians may attempt to sell themselves as feminist icons, despite not contributing to the movement. Feminism may distort voter perceptions to negative ends.
Right-wing female candidates often pander to women voters, appearing to espouse feminist ideals in order to garner more votes.
More women are in C-suite positions in Fortune 500 companies than ever before.
Even the increased number of women on boards represents just 6% of C-suite positions, speaking to the level of past inequality and the success of feminism in correcting inequality.
Many changes facilitated by feminism are too slow. In the G7, just 22% of senior roles are occupied by women and 39% of companies have no women at all in senior roles.
The existence of women leaders in prominent and powerful positions is evidence that equality of opportunity has been achieved; feminism is no longer necessary.

A patriarchal status quo does not exist in many Western societies, as evidenced by women in positions of power. Theresa May, Hillary Rodham Clinton, and Kamala Harris demonstrate the heights women can achieve.
Many companies report that gender parity is a top priority for them, signalling further that equality of opportunity has either been achieved or will be soon.
The US senate is overwhelmingly male, with a sparse handful of current and former female senators.
In 2017, there were only 15 female world leaders in office in the world, eight of whom were their countrys first woman in power.
Given the glass cliff phenomenon, women in leadership do not signal gender parity; equality is only achieved when all positions have roughly equal gender representation.
Women hold fewer positions of power because of their life choices, rather than systemic discrimination. Therefore, feminism has not corrected any injustice by changing preferences.
Though feminists suggest that there is a wage gap, its existence is disputed and is unlikely to have come from sexist origins.
The gendered wage gap is thought to be between 4.8 and 7.1%, which is within one standard deviation. This is insignificant from a statistical standpoint (p. 1).
Women have and take time off to be with their children which causes their career progression to slow, and limits the number who reach the top echelons of business and society.
Women often struggle to find adequate childcare which can make them less reliable employees as they often fill a caring role.
Childbearing, which contributes significantly to the pay gap, is determined by physiology and not influenced by historic or societal sexism.
Couples or families make the decision to have a child; physiology only determines who carries it.
Women may have to pause their careers as their partners seldom do their fair share of parenting or household tasks (p. 165).
Measures of the gender pay gap among recent college graduates show a reverse wage gap; women now make 8% more than their male counterparts.
Factors such as role or hours are determined by societal or historical sexism, and continue to maintain or worsen the pay gap.
Women are paid less for doing the same jobs with the same experience; the only difference therefore is due to sexism.
There may not be a huge gap when you compare men and women in the same job, but female-dominated jobs, such as social care and nursing, are paid less than male-dominated fields.
The gender pay gap is often conflated with the unadjusted pay gap. When all variables other than gender are controlled for, such as hours worked, occupation, education, the pay gap reduces (p. 2).
A 2018 survey of women in the US indicated that on average they earn 18 cents less per dollar than their male peers.
EU figures show an (unadjusted) average 16.2 % gap (2016, gross hourly earnings).
Women were able to reach the top of society before feminism existed. Both Cleopatra and Maria Theresa were leaders of their respective states.
Historically, women could take on roles in business, be merchants, and run apothecaries.
Whilst historically women did not regularly reach the top of society, they still existed in prominent positions, and were successful enough to benefit from regal patronage.
Both Cleopatra and Maria Theresa rose to power due to lineage. Their ascension had nothing to do with their successes.

Both men and women are subject to environmental forces which influence their decisions. With feminism, we can eliminate unfair targeting, and allow more people to enter into careers which previously they may not have considered.
As feminism is polarising and muddies the water around critical cultural issues, it is less capable of making material change than other movements.
Public interest in changing patriarchal structures is limited, as the issue does not have the same appeal as other social dilemmas.
Most definitions of feminism include a recognition of political activism that some may dislike, even if they otherwise agree with the cause's central tenets.
Young women often perceive feminism as being for angry, bra-burning lesbians (pp. 5-6). This alienates them from the movement as they don't wish to face those negative associations.
Polls in the US suggest that as few as 18% of women call themselves a feminist. This is despite more than two-thirds of women in the country supporting equality of the sexes.
Older women are far less likely to support feminism than newer generations.
Recent statistics indicate that as much as 61% of US women identify as feminists.
Women benefit from feminism, even when they don't support it. For example, at one stage, 90% of women opposed women's suffrage, though it now enables more choice in democratic society.
Privileged people are likely to be defensive when made aware of sexism, as they experience guilt and a sense of persecution. This limits the capacity of feminism to make change.
People are not offended by the knowledge that they are more wealthy and better fed than others. Instead, they react negatively when they are framed as responsible for the issue (p. 1).
Many support gender equality, and are optimistic about achieving it in the future.
Despite feminist campaigns against rape culture, some people still consider it to be a myth.

There is no discussion of "murder culture" or other cultures related to crime as they are accepted by society. Were people to accept the prevalance of rape then the focus could move from proving a rape culture exists to ameliorating the issue.
Feminists inflate sexual assault statistics in order to promote the idea of rape culture.
Campus rape claims are distorted by inaccurate studies, as well as the lobbying of feminist activists and a rape prevention industry.
Companies that sell rape prevention devices encourage fear and an individualised response to crime. This undermines change in the long term.
