In a 2021 survey, 97% of UK women reported sexual harassment. Only 67% identify as feminists, so this is unlikely to be inflated through collusion.
Feminists suggest that one in four women on US college campuses have been raped, though this is disputed, and may be as low as one in fifty.
It is a widely acknowledged problem that sexual assault and rape is under-reported and under-prosecuted.
Only a small minority of sexual assault accusations are proven to be false.
Sexual assault reporting is incredibly difficult, regardless of how commonly it is discussed in the media. This discourages false reporting.
Very few false sexual assault allegations are acted upon by police, and even fewer have legal consequences.
Only about 1.8% of reported rapes are proven to be true.
Two to ten percent may be a small percentage of overall sexual assault allegations, yet it is still significant when people consider the scale of harm to those falsely accused.
A third of university age men did not recognise rape without the label, and said that they would commit those acts if there were no consequences. This indicates a culture where rape is normalised.
Films like Revenge of the Nerds depict rape or abuse for comedic purposes. This may create a cognitive disconnect between the term rape and the actions involved.
The trivialisation of 'rape' to become a flippant term may lead to a normalisation of victim blaming which forms a significant part of rape culture.
During the Belfast Rape Trial, the alleged victim was asked if she had been staring at the defendant on the night of the incident - a clear example of victim blaming.

Having entered the pop culture lexicon as a slang term - referring to an act of aggression or destruction against a person or group of people - the word 'rape' is often trivialised. It is commonly used in male-dominated spaces like sports or video game competitions.
Victim-blaming directs the responsibility to change behaviour to prevent rape onto the victim. Feminism redirects this responsibility back the perpetrator, as it ought to be.

Recent discussions that criticise victim blaming behaviour indicate that the phenomenon may be falling out of vogue, despite the trivialisation of the term 'rape.' Given this, the two may be wholly disconnected.
There are a number of pejorative terms used by members of society that do not normalize harmful actions or behaviors, though they may not be reclamatory per se (p. 3).
The news media is complacent in their use of pejorative language, demonstrating the acceptability of certain words.
Society changes over time; hundreds of words that used to be common have fallen out of favor as awareness grows regarding their harmful nature.
Some facets of feminism and CRT (Critical Race Theory) helped convince the AMA (American Medical Association) to change the terminology used by doctors in reference to patients or patient groups.
Many people are unaware of the harmful impact their words have on others and society overall.
Some ignore allegations of sexual misconduct/assault or defend the accused, instead of making changes that could mitigate future harm.
Due to the legal principle of "innocent until proven guilty," it is common for victims in rape trials to be considered untruthful until proven otherwise.
Rapists, especially upper-class white men, receive minimal punishment despite the overwhelming amount of evidence against them.
Often people push for removing those accused of sexual misconduct from their workplace, yet this flies in the face of HR best practices.
While reactions to sexual assault claims can be mishandled, campaigns to change cultural norms and prevent harm are increasingly common and undermine the possible norms of rape culture.
Feminism has facilitated historical progress for gender parity, therefore any polarisation caused by the movement is likely to be minimal.
There is a whole body of feminist literature and theory which can inform activists and help them to side-step the kinds of poor messaging that facilitate polarisation.
There is an international network of feminist activism used to combat injustice. This can be used to share best practices and methods of persuading people.
Feminism's history does not justify its evolution into a modern divisive force. There is no reason to believe that the positive actions of the past will be replicated in the future.
Effective system change can be motivated through close monitoring and considerate donation. This is not exclusive to feminism, so change is possible through many approaches.
Young women increasingly engage with various feminisms on social media, spreading ideas through their offline networks (p. 4). This innovative approach can facilitate change, by passing polarisation.
Social media activism encourages young women to create communities. This mobilisation is incredibly important as it encourages civic engagement amongst the traditionally disenfranchised.
The Instagram infographic industrial complex and general memeification of social issues may dilute their importance, encouraging idle sharing over actions that bring change.

Feminists are often decried as irrational so they gain very little from pointing out sexism where it does not exist. Given this, feminists overwhelmingly call attention to serious real world oppressions to maintain some social respect.
In many cases where feminists identify sexism, it is often very difficult for anyone unaccustomed to perceiving these issues to notice.
Often patriarchy is embedded within bureaucratic systems, which can be difficult to notice as being harmful as their decision making standards are often implicit.
Even though it may not be as obvious, covert sexism holds women back, and is as damaging as more overt forms. As these actions are innocuous, critiquing them can feel like an outsized response.
Cognitive biases blight everyone in society; feminist activists could be prone to confirmation bias as they fit phenomena to hypotheses rather than vice versa.
Some have a vested interest in ignoring the patriarchy, which leads them to disregard feminists' evidence for sexism.
Justifications for maintaining the patriarchy are deeply embedded in society; this stratification can be difficult to unlearn.
Men may feel alienated from society when they hear feminist critiques; this comes from a now dissonant belief that the system was working for them, which has been upended.
Some feminists eschew typical evidentiary standards within their campaigns which can make them hard to trust.
Actions can be interpreted as sexist, regardless of intent. This speaks to the world view of the interpreter instead of the nature of the action itself.
People often have priors that they use to evaluate the intent, context, and meaning of others; the assumed meaning may be quite different from the original intention.
Actions can be sexist without intent; this may arise through miscommunication, cultural misunderstanding, or the normalisation of sexism socially, not necessarily from the interpreter.
Action matters more than intention, especially when associated with systematic disadvantage. Oppressive actions may be carried out with the best intentions.
In spaces that offer additional social protection for the victimised, it can be useful to point out sexism where it is not warranted, to help shield people from criticism.
Calls to victimhood have become mechanisms for the subversion of power by hegemonic groups, disrupting activisms that previously undermined them (p. 4).

While some may exaggerate victimisation for their own gain, such safety is less likely to exist outside of very considerate social justice movements. This makes it more likely that complaints of sexism - as directed by feminists to the outer world - are legitimate.

Society has been structured so as to privilege men over others. Feminism is legitimate in pushing through social reforms on widespread issues resulting from biases that disproportionately affect women - these changes benefit many groups.
Womanhood becomes a salient aspect of political identity to organise around under feminism. This is effective as it targets more people than class or race would.
Feminism has brought hundreds of thousands of women from all demographics and walks of life together in protests and marches, united by a common goal.
Many feminist protests and marches lack a coherent cause or goal, as there are many different perspectives on womanhood and equality.
The 1968 white-women-led protest against Miss America clashed with the counter pageant hosted by Black women. One group sought to abolish pageants whilst the other wanted to expand beauty standards.
The Women's March featured participants who marched for many different reasons; some protested the defunding of Planned Parenthood, others unequal pay, and some the environment.
Protests often have clear goals as, by nature, they react to social issues.
Womanhood is not a monolith, nor is it treated as such by feminists. This limits the persuasiveness of identity as a rallying element.

Wittig argues that lesbians are not women due to their unique social positioning that moves them outside of gender binaries. Analysing how gender is socially maintained is a core aspect of feminist theory.

Whilst womanhood is not monolithic, its performative elements fill a referential function that allow people to build upon similarities. It is this amalgam of experiences that becomes salient and is mobilised by feminists to great effect.
Justice-based feminisms are good for many marginalized groups, as they focus on ways to expose and alter harmful dynamics that are embedded within power structures (p. 151).
Native Americans integrated feminist advocacy strategies into many of their equal rights and anti-bigotry movements (pp. 485-486).

Justice based feminisms are not particularly common in the current era of neoliberal individualistic feminist action. The former group is often harmed by the latter, as group action and critical social engagement are derided.
Feminism has been claimed by groups that have incompatible methods and goals, hindering social reform.
Radical feminism prioritises the breakdown of social structures in order to remake them in a more equitable manner.
As there is no body that regulates feminist thought, there are often ideological incompatibilities within movements. This can be misused to justify intolerance.

Liberal feminism encourages equitable access to existing power structures. It leverages legal systems in order to achieve equality, leaving the structure, its integration in society, and core aspects of social control remaining.
Social reform comes from fostering open dialogue and giving people the tools to think critically about society; feminism could never make change if it was dogmatic and offered only one view.
People are often driven by social acceptance and seek to align their beliefs as such. If feminists are dogmatic then they may alienate allies and make themselves unpersuasive.
By allowing the movement to be aligned with many divergent political stances, feminism has facilitated its co-option by forces that seek to undermine its overall goal.
By normalising different perspectives on how to solve issues and encouraging experimentation, feminists may be able to persuade more people of their legitimacy.

Encouraging dialogue with the aim of perfect consensus hinders action and causes a loss of morale; this has been weaponised by those who oppose change historically, and should not be embedded as a normative practice by activist movements.
Feminists should not encourage divergence as contradictions often undermine trust, particularly when scandals arise. Such strategies harm feminism in the long term.
Feminist methods of striving for equality are detrimental to men.
If feminism aimed to meaningfully advance gender equality it would demand that women be treated equally in situations where they currently are advantaged.
Women do well in many education systems. This would not be feasible if they were still oppressed, and as such, quotas for women in education are illegitimate.
Girls often outperform boys in STEM subjects. Quotas in these fields are therefore unnecessary.
Though women receive more STEM degrees than men, women often prefer to work in health-related industries. These are legitimate choices and indicate opportunity and autonomy.
Despite girl's academic success in STEM, professional fields are dominated by men. This may indicate a pipeline issue deterring them from scientific industries.
Teachers are often subconsciously biased and believe that girls have a lower mathematical ability than boys. This can deter girls and young women from the field and higher paid academic careers.
Girls often believe that women are not as smart as men and grow up doubting their intelligence. This system likely curtails educational progress, especially in competitive fields.
Girls trust their maths and science skills more if they go to a single sex school. This indicates that socialisation is impacting their ability to learn confidently in co-ed schools.
Teachers are beginning to focus on ways to incentivize young girls to stick with STEM subjects, encouraging their participation in the professional fields as well.
Women are more likely to become teachers than men, offering them a crucial space to influence the minds of the next generation; any vestigial sexism is likely to be removed at this stage.
Achievement, or the ability to achieve, does not preclude the existence of systematic obstacles that have existed for generations.
Women are more likely to experience disruption in their education - quotas ensure that places are preserved for them in spite of this.
Often sexism makes life so difficult for girls going to school that, even though they are allowed to attend, they will drop out (p. 1).
When women are allowed equal access to education, they are more likely to achieve the highest levels of qualification.
Despite outperforming men at school, 63% of the time in the US, men receive higher salary offers than women for the same job.
Feminism in legislation is harmfully biased against men.
Feminist activists and lawmakers prioritise women in their campaigns and the crafting of anti-violence legislature.
The National Organization for Women blasted efforts to include gender-inclusive language in the Violence Against Women Act.
Some feminists, such as Mary Koss, have discriminated against men victims of domestic and sexual violence (pp. 206-207).
Spanish gender equality and violence laws frame women as the beneficiaries of legislature, and men as the perpetrators of harm.
Men are increasingly able to mount legal defences to justify the killing of their female sexual partners. Feminists need to prioritise women because of this.
Though some feminists may take reductive views on violence in relationships, not all do.
Women are more likely to receive child custody following divorce, yet feminists do not campaign to remediate this.
In the US, paternity laws commonly discriminate against men; many such laws are supported by feminist groups such as the National Organization of Women, among others.
Courts tend to favour mothers in custody battles, in most Western countries.
Women's rights groups have fought against shared parenting legislation.

Feminists argue that women shouldn't be the default carer, as they often are (p. 4). In an equal society, judgements made regarding child custody would be decided by who is best suited for the task, something made easier through feminist action.
The discrimination in custody battles is not brought on by feminism, nor is it necessarily legally enshrined, so remediation of this issue is unlikely to occur through direct action.
Many custody settlements occur out of court and result in mutual agreement that women should care for the children; this cannot be assailed through legal change.
Laws are more likely to be unjustly biased against women than men, such that any imbalance that feminists may introduce would be limited in its effect.

The legal system and politics in the United States are overwhelmingly dominated by (white) men. These systems are and have been biased against women. If feminism counteracts such biases by demanding equality of rights, then this should be welcomed.
In the US State of Georgia, it is legal to take "upskirt" photos of women without their consent.
One way to advocate for any group, minority or otherwise, is to push for new legislation protecting its constituents' rights, as feminists have done in the US.
The fact that a homogeneous group is in a position of power does not necessarily translate in biased lawmaking for the minority.
Many women are married or in union before age 18 and can experience a host of negative consequences because of this. They need feminists to fight for them as they are unable to do so themselves.
Feminism in the Philippines likely had some influence over the decision to raise the age of consent from 12 to 16 (pp. 11-13).

Given the power the state has over its people, liberatory groups should campaign for all to be treated equally. This is the only way to achieve a just world, so if feminism undermines this it should be called out.
Feminism helps men and has overturned laws unfavourable to them.
Feminists in Illinois campaigned to raise the legal drinking age for women to the same as men.
Feminist politicians have fought for paternal leave, particularly in Scandinavian countries.
As men are often considered the default in society, there are seldom laws that discriminate against them for their gender. For feminism to prioritise them would be futile.
Some feminists have opposed equality in the draft.
Many people have claimed it is biased and outdated to require that only men be eligible for conscription, yet many feminists do not to ameliorate this discrepancy.
While many prominent feminists argue against any draft, they also oppose measures to draft men and women equally. This allows men to continue to be exploited as the draft remains.
The military is often incredibly hostile to women; it would be a dereliction of their duty for feminists to advocate for women to be forced into service, even if it made society ostensibly equal.
Advocating for both civility and equal treatment in the military and the draft would by no means be a dereliction of duty for a feminist, unless feminism is indeed not a force for good.
Feminists have advocated for the inclusion of women in the draft for decades.
Some feminists have campaigned for women's inclusion in the military, including combat roles.
Some feminists argue that the draft strips people of rights. Rather than fighting for it to include women, they fight for it to be eliminated altogether to make the world more fair.
Feminism is not just about gender parity but rather autonomy and justice; it would be illegitimate to apply oppressive systems to all people in the name of equality.

Many feminists disagree with the concept of the nation state, the central structure that requires a military (p. 2). Given this, it would undermine their beliefs to advocate for the military in any manner.

The United States will likely require its citizens to serve in some future conflict, regardless of the current existence of a draft. Deciding to include both women and men in such an eventuality, is in the interest of both gender equality and national security.
It could be reasonably argued that addressing the issue of inequality in the draft will make it easier to abolish (p. 36).
Feminists are making strides towards equal representation in dangerous, low-status jobs.
Feminists make work safer by addressing key data gaps that make current safety mechanisms in high lethality jobs ineffective.
Men are significantly more likely to be injured through the course of their work.

In comparison to men, women do not experience meaningful social advantages, as even benevolent sexism is still sexism. Pushing for feminists to dismantle spaces of only surface level advantage is a waste of their resources.

For women who take on the role of primary caregiver in a heterosexual relationship, the supposed advantages of not having to work and being able to spend more time with children can actually result in social isolation and depression.
Women are often expected to feel lucky to have the choice to be a stay at home parent.
Women who are stay at home caregivers are statistically more likely to suffer mental health struggles than both their working parent and child-free women counterparts.
Postpartum depression is increasingly discussed, with new interventions to help treat the condition (p. 9).
Women may struggle initially to adapt to motherhood, though often find support in mother and baby groups that allow socialisation space and reduce stress (p. 13).

In many places, the duration of parental leave offered to women is significantly greater than that offered to men. This gives them a meaningful advantage in spending time and bonding with their newborn child.
Even when available, men in the US routinely face stigma and shame for taking paternity leave.

As well as allowing time for bonding with their child, maternity leave is designed to help women cope with the biological stresses of the latter stages of pregnancy and the post-birth recovery. This is something men do not have to contend with.
Feminism often restricts its own capacity to produce meaningful change; the movement's methods can be alienating to men.
When men see feminism as a zero-sum game that comes at their expense, progress cannot occur.
Women often need men to help them tackle subtle social problems, such as workplace misogyny. When men do not feel comfortable or want to do so, women suffer.
Sexist stereotypes cannot change solely through political campaigning and feminist leadership; public acceptance is also required.
Men have seldom supported feminism and yet great advancements have arisen; it seems likely that equality can be advanced without 100% support.

MGTOW (Men Going Their Own Way) was formed due to the alienation some men claim to experience because of feminism. The movement is often framed as self-preservation against the changing tides of gender norms.
MGTOW goes as far as to advocate for completely shunning all contact with women, far exceeding anything proposed by feminists.
Misogyny existed before feminism; it is unclear if the movement can be blamed for MGTOW behaviors.
Feminism is often associated with change and a form of liberal progression that destabilises hierarchies. Regardless of the cause, feminism is held accountable for the outcomes, often unfairly.

French far-right writer and TV commentator, Eric Zemmour, uses feminism as a dog-whistle to signal his distaste for social change and gain political support, though it is not clear that women's liberation is responsible for voter malaise.

South Korean men negatively reacted to an Olympic archer who "looked like a feminist;" their reaction was not based on her actions but rather her progressive aesthetic, short hair, and the fact that she attended an all-women's college.
In France, "wokisme" is drastically altering national identities and leaving people behind; feminism is a contributor to this social change.
Some men consider themselves feminists; they don't necessarily see the movement as alienating.
Oftentimes, alt-right groups unfairly represent feminists to radicalise young men; the actions or ideologies of various feminist waves have little impact on this depiction.
Alt-right groups actively denigrate men for associating with feminism, accusing them of being white knights amongst other things, to stop them from subverting power dynamics.
Anti-feminist groups use logical fallacies and false claims to discredit the movement. For example, some may use the fallacy of composition to claim that all feminists hold extremist views.

By normalising misogyny and making it an active part of their outwards presentation, the alt-right silence dissent from progressives by labelling them as emasculated. This allows the alt-right to build power and embed themselves.
Feminists occasionally misstep on social media and present themselves poorly; even if those instances are uncommon, these behaviours can make people skeptical of the movement.
Feminist women who do not always live by their values can alienate men who feel that feminism is merely for social gain, and not for improving the world.
Current feminisms do not oppress or come to the detriment of men. Rather, their critiques of men's power and privileges can be alienating, as they target something often taken for granted.
Third-wave feminism discusses the ways in which power can be used by all groups to enact oppression, including by women to harm men. This is far more holistic than prior theorisations of power.
Third-wave feminism is often considered to be toxic, as it focuses on shaming sexist men rather than engaging with the source of these actions.
Influential feminists have historically been unapologetically misandrist; the newer waves now frame it as "ironic."
Many third-wave feminists cloak distaste for men within cute and kitsch aesthetics, in order to exploit stereotypes and excuse reductive politics.
Though some people could be considered to be toxic feminists, they do not constitute the majority; some argue that toxic feminism is not a real thing.
Men are generally not accustomed to pushback from women; therefore, many men mistakenly associate feminism with oppressive actions that diminish their masculinity and livelihoods.

Boys who are disciplined by their mothers in domineering ways often go on to be aggressive with their peers; this lack of an emotional schema to negotiate criticism from women may carry through to adulthood.

As recently as the 1960s, women were prohibited from doing a number of activities that men could; men are likely to be uncomfortable within these situations, as historically they have held all the power.
Women who assert themselves are often associated with being aggressive or bossy while men doing the same are seen as confident leaders. This double standard often leads men to feel unduly oppressed.
Though men and women may currently enter debates with different standards for engagement, these are likely to be socialised and may shift generationally, leading men to view feminism more positively.
Men and women make equally good bosses provided they flex their leadership style to match the standard of their profession.
Nearly 30% of men feel that feminist progress towards equality has come at the detriment to men.
A quarter of Republican women agree that progress towards gender equality has come at the expense of men.
Feminism has helped men.
Feminism can be considerate of the ways in which both men and women suffer in society.
Many prominent feminists celebrate men and their relationships with them, and have written extensively on masculinity.
Emma Watson, a well-known feminist, has promoted feminism as a way for men to open up and be more sensitive and vulnerable, demonstrating that they don't have to be strong all the time.
Masculinity studies, born out of feminist academia, considers the ways in which men suffer under patriarchy.
The changes that some feminists have advocated for put men in a position where they are fearful of women in the workplace.
Men in positions of power do not feel comfortable having women in their classrooms and offices alone without the door open, for fear of a visit to HR or a harassment lawsuit.
The majority of men do not feel uncomfortable around women.
Since instances of false rape accusations are incredibly rare, the fear of being accused of sexual misconduct is irrational.
Many people get away with rape as few are convicted. This reduces the harm of any possible allegation - false or otherwise.
In many places, marital rape is not considered a crime.
Some rapists are able to marry their victims, instead of being charged.
The FBI updated their definition of rape, this could lead to an increased number of cases that would be considered rape and subsequent convictions.
Woman are unlikely to report sexual assault, which decreases the likelihood of even a true allegation.
The trauma of having been raped is not dissimilar to that of war-induced PTSD in soldiers; this likely prevents many women from coming forward with their stories.
Even when men are charged with sexual assault they do not seem to face severe consequences.
Pedophiles can keep working with children.
Rapists can still gain custody over the child in some states.
The sentence for rape in some countries is life in prison, castration, or even death.

Rape accusations are only irrational if you're part of the majority group; Black men in the US are overwhelmingly more likely to be accused than their white counterparts, likely fuelled by a dangerous history of presumed sexual immorality.
Some feminists are chauvinistic and seek to devalue men in order to emphasise the role of women in society.
Prominent feminists have made a number of general statements against men.
Men are sometimes blamed by feminists for problems they may only have indirect responsibility for.

The "Give Your Money to Women" campaign suggested that all men alive should be held responsible for inequality and injustice; the campaign founders claim that redistributing men's money to women would be an acceptable form of reparations for harms caused, though this is often a reductive approach.
Though men may not have directly contributed to the patriarchy, they do benefit from it. This creates an obligation to fix the unjust system.
Some feminist texts discuss the value in hating and physically harming men.
Some feminists have taken texts that advocate violence against men literally and caused physical harm to others.
Author of the radical feminist SCUM Manifesto, Valerie Solanas was imprisoned for the attempted murder of Andy Warhol.
Donna Hylton was invited by prominent feminists to speak at the International Women's March, despite having been convicted of murder and torture.
Some radical second wave feminists posited that the population of men should be reduced to 10%.
Given that women seldom possess social power, their advocacy for harmful political action, even if distasteful, is toothless.
Despite the fact that feminists advocate on occasion for harming men, it is likely that there have been more feminists killed in shootings by men than female mass-shooters generally.
Assuming they do not act on their misandry, which is incompatible with mainstream feminism, misandrists still deserve equal rights, all other things held equal.
Though some feminists are anti-men, feminism itself is not based on anti-masculinity.
Until feminism actively demonstrates a willingness to eradicate anti-men feminist voices, it will continue to be associated with being anti-men.
Men struggle with the discrimination and harassment they face with a chauvinistic partner.
Evidence points to feminists finding sexist, more masculine men more attractive than men who identify as feminists.
Feminism doesn't have a specific set of rules that every feminist must adhere to.

It is unreasonable to expect participants of a movement to catch all instances of inappropriate behavior from other members. These actions should not be cause for the wholesale dismissal of a historically-significant movement.
Female chauvinists propagate the idea that women are better than men, or that the two are enemies; in reality, this is a minority view amongst feminists.
Radical facets of feminism aim to disrupt and dismantle the patriarchy as a root cause of inequality, mitigating its harmful implications for men and boys.
Women are perceived as weak and unfit for dangerous roles, placing extra responsibility on men.
Men are often seen to be the protectors of women and family, meaning they may feel obligated to risk their lives in combat or other dangerous activities.
Men have often sacrificed themselves in times of disaster and tragedy, going to great lengths to keep others safe.
Sometimes men aren't given the choice of risking their lives; most of the men who have fought in wars over history were conscripted or taken away from their families to fight.
Men often do much more difficult, dangerous work; they may be coerced to do so by presumptions that physical exertion is manly (p. 2).
On average, women are physically weaker than men. This is a consequence of human biology and not societal perceptions, and as such men are obliged to protect them to better society.
Men tend to have more skeletal muscle mass than women making them more suited to physical combat.
Science actually demonstrates that women are stronger than men with regards to longevity and the ability to survive illness and deal with trauma.
Stuntwomen are tougher than stuntmen because they are disadvantaged in action roles; their skimpy outfits put them at greater risk for injury.
Feminists are trying to break the cycle of toxic masculinity that prevents men from speaking out about their struggles.
In a patriarchal society, men are discouraged from speaking out about being victims of sexual assault because they're told that men either "can't be raped" or "should have enjoyed it."
Toxic masculinity is linked to an increased rate of suicide amongst men who hold such views, feminism will save lives by addressing this issue.
Men often feel they cannot talk about mental health struggles without being made to feel theyre being unmanly or too feminine for expressing emotions (pp. 6-7). They still need feminism.
Feminism is needed to challenge and reframe the negative stereotypes that exacerbate men's mental health struggles and prevent them from seeking help.
Lifestyle factors are significant contributors for male suicide; reducing the pressure on men to succeed is likely to help address this fatal trend (p. 2).
Patriarchal gender roles may not be the root cause of issues such as male suicide, rather many people have genetic predispositions that make mental disorders more likely to manifest.
Higher male suicide rates are associated with the use of more lethal methods by men, as women attempt more often (p. 1). Feminism is unlikely to be able to meaningfully change this trend.
By raising the status of women in society, feminism reduces the influence of toxic masculinity (p. 17).
As women gain greater influence and respect in society, their perspectives significantly diminish the tolerability or acceptability of misogynistic attitudes.
Discussions of toxic masculinity are often reductive or stigmatising. This closes off conversations before they can even begin.
Feminism has had a harmful effect on young boys who are no longer given as much emphasis on freedom as their female peers.
Feminist parenting techniques can prevent young boys from reaching their full potential; the lack of encouragement can cause them to become discouraged more easily.
Though young boys may face some discursive limitations, they overwhelmingly have more freedom in their households to do what they want, when they want (p. 1).
Feminists are often against a man's right to choose fatherhood.
A man's right to choose fatherhood is independent of a woman's choice regarding the viability of her pregnancy, yet is often ignored in discussions of reproductive choice.
Most safe-haven laws in the United States deprive a father of the right to choose fatherhood (p. 19).

Mothers are able to require men to pay child support, despite refusing access to their child. This can happen even if the father had zero involvement in the decision to become pregnant, and may be inescapable, forcing them into situations they had no choice in.
Men are instrumentalized when they are forced to support a child they didn't want to have, as they neither consent to being used as mere means to an end, nor do they share in that end (p. 180).
Feminists can and do advocate for men's right to choose (or rather reject) fatherhood. It is not a central tenet of their activism though as the harms to men are merely monetary.
Monetary harms in this context do not stand alone, and can lead to psychological harms (pp. 1-2), loss of time, work, reputation, and autonomy (p. 23).
As child support is often only state mandated in situations of low income; parents should not be able to opt out in case it harms the child's quality of life.

Social media content often highlights how fathers may not fully understand the costs associated with child rearing, how a lack of maintenance payments negatively impacts their children, and how widespread the problem is.
Lack of sufficient funds can have a severe impact on a child's quality of life and cognitive abilities, both at the time of the deprivation and into adulthood.

Despite many states establishing laws that protect sperm donors in cases of AID, men who have sex that results in pregnancy, regardless of intent, can be coerced into parenthood and therefore child support payments (p. 28).
Feminists do not criticise laws that harm men's right to choose fatherhood in the same way that they advocate for women's right to choose motherhood.
Single men looking to adopt are often treated with undue skepticism (p. 83); something that receives little attention from feminists.
In some countries, trans people and gay men are prohibited from adopting children; feminists tend to be silent on the issue.
Some feminists argue to expand theorisations of reproductive justice to gay men, enabling them procreative liberties that allow them greater access to fatherhood (p. 131).

Only those currently pregnant should be allowed to make decisions about the viability of their foetus. Instrumentalisation is unjust in any scenario, yet it is required under right to choose legislation that allows men to veto women's abortion requests.

Allowing "only those who gestate" to make these decisions would exclude a number of trans women, infertile women, and others from decisions on foetal viability and the accessibility of medical intervention.
As men may be able to coerce their partners into bearing more children, feminists advocating for men to have more influence in reproductive decisions is counterintuitive.
Enshrining a person's right to choose and control their own reproductive system is especially important in areas where there are gendered gaps in family size expectations (p. 31).
The fact that men suffer from a patriarchal system does not mean that they require feminism.
Advocating for women to have equal rights does not automatically save men from potentially being hurt by the patriarchy (p. 22).
Men often feel that they cant express themselves without ridicule. The conversations facilitated by feminism improve this to achieve equity.
